title: Free Talks: Barbara Kopple and Sharon Jones (Miss Sharon Jones!)
event_desc: Join two-time Academy Award-winner Barbara Kopple (Harlan County USA, American Dream) and Grammy-nominated R&B singer Sharon Jones as they discuss Kopple’s upcoming documentary.

title: Free Talks: Greg Kinnear and Ira Sachs (Little Men)
event_desc: Oscar-nominee Greg Kinnear (As Good as It Gets) will join New York filmmaker Ira Sachs (Love Is Strange, Keep the Lights On) to discuss their new film, which opens here at the Film Society on August 5.

title: Howards End
event_desc: Rarely has a screen adaptation of a work of classic literature been pulled off with as much intelligence, power, and artistry as James Ivory and Ismail Merchant’s film of E. M. Forster’s Howards End, starring an Oscar-winning Emma Thompson in her star-making role.

title: Indian Point
event_desc: Indian Point Energy Center, an aging nuclear power plant, looms just 45 miles north of Midtown Manhattan. Capturing the steeping arguments for clean energy and the catastrophic risks of government complacency, Ivy Meeropol’s Indian Point is a revelatory film about the uncertainty of our nuclear future and our insatiable demands for energy.

title: Norman Lear: Just Another Version of You
event_desc: Norman Lear—the legendary, influential mind behind 1970s sitcoms like All in the Family, The Jeffersons, and Maude—reflects on his life, his work, and the extraordinary change in national consciousness sparked by his revolutionary television shows.

title: Summertime
event_desc: A portrait of a young woman caught between her conservative rural parents and the older Parisian feminist organizer she’s come to love, Catherine Corsini’s prizewinning new melodrama ventures confidently and gracefully into fraught emotional territory. A Rendez-Vous with French Cinema 2016 selection.

title: Warren Oates: Hired Hand
event_desc: With his rough-hewn face and gruff demeanor, Warren Oates had the kind of offbeat, chameleon-like screen presence that could only have belonged to a star of the freewheeling New Hollywood of the 1960s and ’70s. On the occasion of a new digital restoration of Leslie Stevens’s Private Property, featuring Oates in his first significant screen role, the Film Society will celebrate the actor’s inimitable stamp on classics of the American New Wave and cult favorites alike.
